title: Glimpsing through Meditation
text: I was first introduced to formal practice of meditation when I was in lower secondory school. After that there were many instances of following spiritual schools and gurus for the sake of learning how to meditate. It was never consistent and I was never consistent. In the past few months, I have been fairly consistent meditating just by myself. Without a teacher, however, learning the skill of meditation is not an easy task to undertake. After weighing the pros and cons, I decided to learn from a teacher, from someone who is trained and knows better, someone who can teach. I came across this app by Sam Harris in which there are different courses and routes of meditation practice including one for beginners. [Sam is generally known for his expression on politics, philosophy and religion. But this is not my concern at the moment.] Today marks the 25th day of my regular practice of following the guided meditation. I would recommend it to anyone. With the practice, I have begun to realize those aspects of ‚Äòmyself‚Äô that had gone unnoticed earlier, or had been noticed in readings. I have questions about life and existence, about self and consciousness more than ever before. Probably this also depends on what one seeks from meditation. Why do you (want to) meditate? Do you think that meditation is the remedy to all the problems in your life: stress, negative emotions, anger and so on?

title: Why not pick your brain
text:
I‚Äôve put together links to some wikipedia articles that helped me refresh my high school maths, and gain some new knowledge. Wanna see?

Glosarry of mathematical symbols

Domain of a function
Codomain of a function

Predicate (in matematical logic)
Limit ordinal

Perhaps, some day in a distant future, I will write about applying these ideas in my work, or not. Let‚Äôs see.

title: Some gitting
text:
Some of the most frequently used git commands‚Ä¶

git push -u origin master #to push to the remote repo for the first time
git checkout -b NewBranchName
git push -u origin BranchIamWorkingOn #to push from local repo to remote repo if the remote repo doesn't have this `BranchIamWorkinOn` setup up already
git branch -D BranchToBeDeleted

To merge

git checkout main #First switch to the main/master branch
git merge BranchIwantToMerge #The branch still exists after merging

title: Pratik Bhandari
text:
Hello there! Welcome to my site.
I am a doctoral researcher at the Collaborative Research Center (Sonderforschungsbereichs ‚Äì SFB 1102) at Saarland University, Department of Psychology and Department of Language Science and Technology. Prof.¬†Jutta Kray and Prof.¬†Vera Demberg are my advisors.
My PhD research is focused on how we make sense of spoken language under adverse listening conditions. I study when (and how) context helps us understand degraded speech, and when context is not much helpful.
I expect to complete my PhD by the end of September this year. Offers for postdoc positions are welcome :)

title: Glimpsing through Meditation
text: I was first introduced to formal practice of meditation when I was in lower secondory school. After that there were many instances of following spiritual schools and gurus for the sake of learning how to meditate. It was never consistent and I was never consistent. In the past few months, I have been fairly consistent meditating just by myself. Without a teacher, however, learning the skill of meditation is not an easy task to undertake. After weighing the pros and cons, I decided to learn from a teacher, from someone who is trained and knows better, someone who can teach. I came across this app by Sam Harris in which there are different courses and routes of meditation practice including one for beginners. [Sam is generally known for his expression on politics, philosophy and religion. But this is not my concern at the moment.] Today marks the 25th day of my regular practice of following the guided meditation. I would recommend it to anyone. With the practice, I have begun to realize those aspects of ‚Äòmyself‚Äô that had gone unnoticed earlier, or had been noticed in readings. I have questions about life and existence, about self and consciousness more than ever before. Probably this also depends on what one seeks from meditation. Why do you (want to) meditate? Do you think that meditation is the remedy to all the problems in your life: stress, negative emotions, anger and so on? Maybe this is not the right approach to meditation, I opine. I definitely do not qualify to make a seasoned claim. But gleaning what I have glimpsed in recent days and what I had learnt from my intermittent practice in the past is that meditation is not the means to attain those ends. Meditation, I think, is about being mindful of the existence ‚Äì existence of thoughts, emotions, feelings, sensations in one‚Äôs conscious awareness. Realizing and observing that all what we experience in our waking hours (probably while we sleep as well) are merely the appearance of those experiences in the field of conscious awareness. And we identify this experience as ‚Äòself‚Äô, an illusory self. This realization, even if momentary in the beginning, is enlightening [I am not using the word ‚Äòenlightening‚Äô in the same sense that is used in different Buddhits and Hindu traditions.] I can‚Äôt say for sure if I am under an illusion that I have glimpsed it: there are instances during meditation when I have momentarily observed the non-existence of ‚Äòself‚Äô; there is no ‚ÄòI‚Äô. This might as well an illusion at the end. With time and practice, things will be clearer for me. Afterall, you can see how many times the word ‚ÄòI‚Äô has been used in this writing ‚Äì the self is so dominant. And semantics does matter, doesn‚Äôt it?

title: What‚Äôs new?
text:
My work on the effect of speech rate on degraded speech comprehension has been accepted for poster presentation at the IMPRS Conference 2022 to be held at MPI Psycholinguistics (Nijmegen, Netherlands) in June 01-03.
My work on the role of attention on degraded speech comprehension has been accepted for poster presentation at the APS Annual Convention 2022 in Chicago in May 26-29..

title: Relaxed restrictions in Saarbr√ºcken
text:
Anyway, the point is ‚Äì to book a table for a weekend lunch, or an evening drink in a pub you need to get a rapid antigen test report. If the test result is negative, you are a free bird for 24 hours!
Here you can find more details and book an online appointment for the test.


Enjoy your social life responsibly üòè‚Ä¶until the number of cases reaches the threshold of danger leading back to restrictions.

See you somewhere in Tante Anna or Wallys Pub ‚Äì my favorites.






Or perhaps on a walk by the river üòå (and make me complete)










Footnotes


Check the websites of Robert Koch Institute and Saarland state government for official information, rules and regulations. The information in this page are taken from the news sources ‚Äì [1] and [2].‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: A bit of git-ting
text:
This post is to remind myself of most frequently used git commands.


# Push local changes to the remote repo:
git push -u origin master

# Creat and checkout new branch:
git checkout -b NewBranchName

git push -u origin BranchIamWorkingOn # to push from local repo to remote repo if the remote repo doesn't have this `BranchIamWorkinOn` setup up already

# Delete a local branch:
git branch -D BranchToBeDeleted

Be careful on deleting. The -D is a hard delete!
Merge branches locally:

git checkout main #First switch to the main/master branch
git merge BranchIwantToMerge #The branch still exists after merging

This was a dirty note down as I frequently make mistakes using these commands. git pull, git merge, etc. are also used but not much problematically.
Tune in for more frequently used R and bash scripts :D

title: Sky divided
text: Republished in April 2021

title: In the operating room
text:
‚ÄúMy name is Nurse Mark. You are in the operation room. Do you understand Miss Maya?‚Äù I nod my head. He seems to not understand. I say ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù He smiles. He moves me under two big inverted-umbrella like monsters. They look like some sort of constellation of LED-lights you often see in Gray‚Äôs Anatomy. Suddenly they glow and my eyes are blinded for a moment. Dr.¬†Glassman is here.
‚ÄúHello, Maya! How are you doing?‚Äù
‚ÄúOkay. Waiting it to start and get over with. You are using local, right?‚Äù
‚ÄúGood then. You didn‚Äôt want general. So.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôve already experienced your general anesthesia. This time I want to be awake the whole time. I want to see you operate on me. I mean, how it works.‚Äù
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see if you can see. You know that there will be a drape.‚Äù
Oh crap. I‚Äôd forgotten about the drape. They hide my head.
‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

He moves the surgical display monitor here and there. (This is fancy!) I can see my chest on it. Reminds of Dashain when after beheading a goat men in the village would shave it off and apply turmeric powder on it‚Äôs body before cutting it into pieces. Betadine had made my chest look just like the goat‚Äôs yellow stomach. I still have my head intact and Dr.¬†Glassman is not Frankenstein.
Mark arranges drape around me. The monitor is hidden now. All I see is Green. Anaesthesia is already doing its job ‚Äì I can no longer feel my chest. A guy comes near my ear and says, ‚ÄúYou will feel dizzy and a bit cold. I have given a medication.‚Äù I read his name ‚ÄúDr.¬†Truman, Anaesthesia‚Äù; I chuckle. Mark had opened an IV line for him in my left arm.
Wait! Didn‚Äôt Dr.¬†Glassman just say local anaesthesia? Why would I feel dizzy? Did Truman just say I won‚Äôt be able to move? How will I breath then? They had already put oxygen tube in and around my nose. Am I duped into all this? God.
My head! It‚Äôs hurting now. I feel tired. Sleepy. Why are my eyelids closing? I don‚Äôt want to sleep. I just want to experience everything that happens during the operation. I am here also to remind Dr.¬†Glassman to take pictures. (He has an iPhone, better than mine.) MRI images do not satisfy the eagerness of human eyes. A piece of paper with numbers on it does not give you the picture. Doctors might form an image out if it, but I have to see the thing itself. Don‚Äôt you wish to see the face of your killer before he is sentenced to death? Just that you don‚Äôt survive the murder attempt, and death sentences are either not possible, or are not real solutions. Still, the wish remains. Sorry, I went a bit emotional. Philosophical.
Struggling not to close the eyelids, I ask Dr.¬†Glassman how is it going there. He doesn‚Äôt say a thing.
Loud. ‚ÄúHey Doctor. I don‚Äôt want to sleep. I will sing songs. Is that okay?‚Äù
‚ÄúHmm‚Äù
I don‚Äôt know if he is talking to me or saying something to the other assisting doctor.

I don‚Äôt care. I can‚Äôt care. I first go with Nabin K Bhattarai: ‚ÄúKhadai nakhako bish le jyudai maryo‚Äù. Then some of Coldplay I think. English, Nepali, Hindi all mixed up ‚Äì my frustrations are spelled out then: ‚ÄòFuck‚Äô, ‚ÄòMuji‚Äô, ‚ÄòMadarchod‚Äô, ‚Ä¶ Some ill-formed sentences to some loving motherfuckers. I get them all out. Everyone here has their own shit to care about to make the operation successful despite my practice for the audition of Nepal Idol and Himalaya Roadies.

Breathing is getting difficult. Someone is stabbing me. My chest hurts. I turn left ‚Äì the clock says 3:30. Does the anaesthesia wear off after 1 hour? When did they give the anaesthesia? It is all because I resisted sleep. People say sleep is important. Or maybe I just dozed off due to the anaesthesia and this is a dream. I will wake up without any pain. But what about this pain right now? Remember what Descartes said: what you feel is real. Did he really say that? Fuck Descartes. He never experienced anaesthesia. Screw all armchair philosophers who don‚Äôt have any experience of altered consciousness.

Needles on my chest. Ahhh!!! No!!!
Is Dr.¬†Glassman already sewing? I clinch my fist on every penetration of the needle.
‚ÄúWow, the surgery was short!‚Äù
Nothing.
Louder. ‚ÄúNo.¬†It hurts!‚Äù
Nothing.
Don‚Äôt they hear me? Am I just speaking inside my head? Or am I just, paralyzed? I‚Äôll be one of those stories of patients being awake during surgeries feeling all the pain but unable to speak.

The pain is getting unbearable. In pain, minutes feel like eternity. When the pain is beyond ‚Äòunbearable‚Äô, the concept of time evaporates into ether. It is just pain and you. I am with pain now.

‚ÄúCongratulations! We have removed the tumor.‚Äù Dr.¬†Glassman removes the drape and winks with his usual ‚ÄúCancer is canceled.‚Äù
I look down where my breast used to be. Sure, ‚ÄòCancer is canceled.‚Äô

title: An apology
text:
The horrible things spoken and done
Hurt
Me,
Filled with pain and sorrow ‚Äì
Every walking, living shadow
Is scary
These days
I see your tears in their dark eyes
I hear you cry in their breath
Do you see me cry?
Do you hear my tears roll down?

Intolerable guilt,
The burden of regret too heavy to carry
Is crushing me
Breaking me into pieces
with some fragments of you in it.

Oh Enough.

To let me live
To set me free
and break the chain
I come to you
And declare in silence ‚Äì
I am sorry.
‚Ä¶I guess

title: My melanin
text:
Beauty is in the eyes of beholder you say,
You define beauty,
A quality one.
You classify beautiful,
An attractive one.
Disgusting is instinctive to you,
Ugly is intuitive to you.
Oh dear,
Now I board
on with your eyes.

You find something off with my nose
Are they protruded too much?
My face screams not enough
Are the eyes in the right place?
Even my bookshelves howl my ugliness ‚Äì
I can‚Äôt fetch you,
The Book on The Bookshelf
A hundred-paged Kamashutra.
Oh, the kind one ‚Äì
You still
behold me
in your eyes.

What do these beholder‚Äôs eyes say,
oh the kind one?
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇIt was not something that was off ?
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇNot the bookshelves that revealed my ugliness ?
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇNot the face that screamed ugly ?
A chromatic affinity?
All not white is what I have.
Mud is what I am,
Alas it disgusted you ‚Äì
Melanin in my skin.

title: Nobody-s
text:
Republished in April 2021




Footnotes


This poem is inspired in part by Emily Dickinson‚Äôs I‚Äôm Nobody! Who are you?‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Strangers again
text:
Short journey:
started as strangers,
the two walked as one.
The ups and downs never tired us.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† (until we got tired of each other)
The sharp saw never ripped us apart.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† (until we ripped each other into pieces)
Here we are,
completing the loop ‚Äì
ended up as strangers.
Congratulations!
We made a full circle today
Republished in April 2021
